messageBody:
Not a direct critic but just my opinion:

If you go with with option #1 or #2 it's quite the same (a matter of
taste) and it's really easy to go from one option to another (maybe a
little bit painfull with cvs and moving files...).

> -keeps the test code close to the packages being developed so that they aren't easily forgotten.

in case you forget to test? :-)

> -makes it easy to compile the test classes with the production code which makes it more likely that developers will keep the test cases up to date and in sync with the production code.

Test code is part of the application as well as the production code.
The test code _must_ be treated like the application code (f.e. checked
in in cvs). It the developers don't want to write tests or keep test
cases up to date it's not by mixing prod and test codes in the same
location that you will find a solution.

I would go this way:
- option #1 with a cvs tree
- regularly check out the production and test code from cvs into a new
directory and JUnit-test the application. So you know if prod and test
codes are in sync.
- have metrics to see how well you've tested your code (# of tests, # of
asserts, how well tests cover the code) so you know if developers have
written test code.
- for the release version, check out the prod code into a new directory,
build the release, give it to the QA. So you know if developers have
written the right code.

My 2 cents

-Vladimir
